channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Riksbank Cuts Key Rate and Signals Further Easing Is Unlikely
item.description: Sweden’s central bank reduced its key policy rate to 1.75% and suggested the cut could mark the final monetary easing of the current cycle.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Chopping

item.title: EU, Indonesia Ink Trade Deal After Years of Talks
item.description: Indonesia will gradually reduce its tariff on imported cars, opening the door for EU auto exports and investment in electric vehicles, among others.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: The worker visas that President Trump says now require $100,000 application fees fill a tiny portion of the U.S. workforce but include jobs at some of the biggest tech companies
item.description: Visas used for skilled workers fill a tiny portion of the U.S. workforce but include jobs at some of the biggest technology companies.
item.dc:creator: Alana Pipe

item.title: Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said inflation concerns would make him hesitant for now to declare support for cutting rates again in October
item.description: The Atlanta Fed president, Raphael Bostic, said risks of weaker employment outcomes have risen, but years of elevated inflation remain a serious concern.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: A full transcript of WSJ’s Nick Timiraos’s interview with Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic
item.description: Bostic spoke about the outlook for the labor market, inflation and interest rates during an interview with Wall Street Journal reporter Nick Timiraos.

item.title: As President Trump doubles down on fossil fuels, the U.S. and China offer competing visions for the future of energy
item.description: As President Trump doubles down on fossil fuels, the U.S. and China offer competing visions for the future of energy.
item.dc:creator: Brian Spegele

item.title: Some economists cite a body of research suggesting that the program has benefited U.S. workers, and the U.S. economy, far more than it has hurt
item.description: Changes to the H-1B system could benefit some U.S. workers. But economists say losing foreign talent could weaken the overall job market—and shift production overseas.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Stephen Miran argues for aggressive interest-rate cuts in a television interview, signaling he is likely to stay closely aligned with President Trump’s demands for lower rates
item.description: The newest Fed governor breaks ranks with board members, saying he doesn’t see inflation from tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The Bank of Japan said it would start to offload its huge portfolio of exchange-traded funds, a sign of growing confidence in the economy
item.description: Billions in sales are planned in a program that could take decades.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: The Fed’s rate cut will likely reduce U.S. borrowing costs for short-term Treasury bills, but annual interest expense won’t shrink much
item.description: The move will likely reduce U.S. borrowing costs for short-term Treasury bills, but annual interest expense won’t shrink much.
item.dc:creator: Richard Rubin

item.title: U.S. Leading Indicators Continue to Show Weakening Economy
item.description: The U.S. economy faces a slowing economy amid growing concerns about the labor market, headwinds from tariffs and a weak manufacturing sector, according to a basket of economic indicators.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined sharply last week, returning the figures to the previous trend after a large spike the week before.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The Bank of England left its key interest rate unchanged, but scaled back a program designed to shrink its holdings of government bonds
item.description: The U.K.’s central bank left its key rate at 4% as policymakers are growing increasingly worried about a pickup in inflation.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: ECB Doesn’t Know If Easing Cycle Is Over, De Guindos Says
item.description: The ECB’s vice president said that, while the risk that inflation will fall below the 2% target over the medium term wasn’t big, a further cut in the key rate couldn’t be ruled out.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: With the Fed in cutting mode, many people expect mortgage rates to fall fast. Unfortunately, it isn’t that simple.
item.description: While the Federal Reserve has begun cutting rates again, there are many other factors that affect the cost of home loans.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Housing Starts Declined More Than Expected in August
item.description: Home-building slumped last month, as mortgage rates remained high and amid an uncertain environment for building-materials prices.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: In her first public comments since Trump fired her, the former head of the government agency that measures inflation and job growth called her dismissal “a dangerous step” for the economy
item.description: In first public remarks since Trump removed her, Erika McEntarfer says she wanted to modernize federal statistics but the agency got caught in DOGE’s crosshairs.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Japan’s Exports Struggle Under Weight of Tariffs
item.description: The negative impact of higher tariffs on Japan has become more apparent, with the country’s exports staying weak in August as U.S.-bound shipments fell further.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: BLS Resumes Hiring of Price Checkers
item.description: The BLS has posted job openings for more than two-dozen part-time workers, some of the first hiring the agency has done after a freeze enacted by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: EU Exports Dip Despite U.S. Rebound
item.description: European exports dropped slightly in July, but the amount of goods headed toward the U.S. picked up after a fall in June.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Average U.K. House Asking Prices Rise in September
item.description: Average costs for homes rose for the first time in four months, but they were lower than where they were a year ago as sellers cut prices over the summer.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: In the weeks since President Trump’s 50% tariffs on Indian imports took effect, apparel, food and jewelry businesses on central New Jersey’s Oak Tree Road are wrestling with how to cope
item.description: In the weeks since President Trump’s 50% tariffs on Indian imports took effect, apparel, food and jewelry businesses on central New Jersey’s Oak Tree Road are wrestling with how to cope.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: The unemployment rate is low. But a measure that includes part-time workers who want a full-time job and people so discouraged they’ve stopped looking is much higher
item.description: The official unemployment rate in the U.S. remains low, but there are signs of struggle for people looking for stable, full-time work.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed Set to Cut Rates; Policy Decisions Due in Japan, Canada, U.K.
item.description: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to resume cutting interest rates on Wednesday by a quarter percentage point.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires staff

item.title: Homebuilders in Tight Spot as Profits Sink, Regional Markets Shift
item.description: Companies are facing reduced margins thanks to surplus inventory in some regions and high demand in others.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller

item.title: Beijing Warns Mexico Against Tariffs That Could Harm Chinese Goods
item.description: Beijing has warned Mexico to think twice before moving ahead with a plan to raise tariffs that could hurt Chinese automakers, saying it would retaliate against the measure.

item.title: The beleaguered housing market could see some relief after mortgage rates fell this week to their lowest level in nearly a year
item.description: Buyers have more purchasing power with lower rates, but home prices near record highs and a weakening job market are significant hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Gina Heeb

item.title: Mexico plans to raise tariffs on imports of key goods from countries with which it doesn’t have a trade agreement as it seeks to bolster domestic industry and substitute imports from Asia
item.description: Proposed legislation would increase tariffs on goods from countries that don’t have a trade agreement with Mexico, such as China.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Harrup

item.title: Census Bureau data show that average U.S. households haven’t gained ground economically since the Covid-19 pandemic struck
item.description: High-income households fared better than others, while women lost ground to men, according to Census Bureau data.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Eurozone Posts Marginal Economic Growth in 2Q, But ECB Rate Cut Remains Unlikely
item.description: Across the 20 nations that share the euro, GDP was 0.1% higher than the first quarter, a sharp slowdown from the 0.6% expansion in the first three months of the year.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Eurozone Unemployment Rate Fell To Match Record Low In July
item.description: The result comes despite weak economic growth, underpinning expectations that the ECB will leave its key interest rate unchanged next week.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending
item.description: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending.
item.dc:creator: Alison Sider

item.title: German Consumers Feel Ever Gloomier as Economy Slumps
item.description: Concerns around unemployment drove the cautious mood among German shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Consumers Sunnier as BOE Cuts Rates But Economic Fears Remain
item.description: U.K. consumers felt a little better about their finances this month as the Bank of England lowered borrowing costs, though sentiment remains weak amid wider economic turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Anxious shoppers, concerned about inflation and their personal finances, are cutting their spending to focus on essentials
item.description: Generic brands and bulk buying are on the rise as shoppers find themselves in a summer of economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Contracts as U.S. Front-Running Cools
item.description: A surge in exports to the U.S. which led Ireland to far outstrip the growth rates of other rich economies waned in the three months through June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
